CodeItem.nci_definition: Discrete, small lesions present in the cornea as a result of corneal inflammation and, in some cases, after soft contact lens wear especially extended-wear lenses.
Replacement of corneal tissue with scar tissue as a result of injury to the deeper layers of the cornea.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Complications of intraocular lens surgery; usually refers to intraocular lens contact with cornea, can be intermittent or chronic.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Complications of intraocular lens surgery; usually refers to intraocular lens contact with cornea, can be intermittent or chronic.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Area of epithelial tissue loss from corneal surface; associated with inflammatory cells in the cornea and anterior chamber.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Area of epithelial tissue loss from corneal surface; associated with inflammatory cells in the cornea and anterior chamber.
A sustained, sudden and involuntary contraction of a muscle or group of muscles.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The patient becomes contaminated from contact with blood/fluids on a device.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The patient becomes contaminated from contact with blood/fluids on a device.
Traumatic compression of the body or a part of the body.
A split located on a leaflet of a heart valve that prevents its complete closing, which can result in valvular dysfunction.
A bluish or purplish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes resulting from a reduced concentration of oxygenated hemoglobin in the blood.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inflammation of the ciliary body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammation of the ciliary body.
A morphologic finding indicating the presence of cystic structures in a tissue sample.
Inflammation of the retina due to cytomegalovirus.

A genus of the family herpesviridae, subfamily betaherpesvirinae, infecting the salivary glands, liver, spleen, lungs, eyes, and other organs, in which they produce characteristically enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusions.
An inherited or acquired condition characterized by the inability to hear in one or both ears.
The cessation of life.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Death in utero; failure of the product of conception to show evidence of respiration, heart beat, or definite movement of a voluntary muscle after expulsion from the uterus, with no possibility of resuscitation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Death of a fetus after 10 weeks gestation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Shedding of accumulated bone fragments.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Shedding of accumulated bone fragments.
A splitting open of an anatomical structure, zone, or organ with the exposure or discharge of its content.
A condition resulting from the excessive loss of water from the body. It is usually caused by severe diarrhea, vomiting or diaphoresis.
Loss of intellectual abilities interfering with an individual's social and occupational functions. Causes include Alzheimer's disease, brain injuries, brain tumors, and vascular disorders.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A severe, often fatal encephalopathy which has been attributed to accumulation in the brain of aluminum from dialysate prepared with inadequately purified water.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A severe, often fatal encephalopathy which has been attributed to accumulation in the brain of aluminum from dialysate prepared with inadequately purified water.
Accumulation of extraneous inorganic matter in tissues or cavities.
A melancholy feeling of sadness and despair.
Inflammation of the skin and muscle.

An eye emergency condition which may lead to blindness if left untreated. It is characterized by the separation of the inner retina layers from the underlying pigment epithelium. Causes include trauma, advanced diabetes mellitus, high myopia, and choroid tumors. Symptoms include sudden appearance of floaters, sudden light flushes, and blurred vision.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Issue associated with the inability to retrieve device and/or device fragments during medical procedures.
A type of metabolic acidosis produced by accumulation of ketone bodies resulting from uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The metabolic condition resulted from uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, in which the shift of acid-base status of the body toward the acid side because of loss of base or retention of acids other than carbonic acid is accompanied by the accumulation of ketone bodies in body tissues and fluids.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Pertaining to or characterized by, or promoting diaphoresis; an agent that produces diaphoresis. (Diaphoresis is the act of perspiration, especially profuse perspiration).
CodeItem.nci_definition: Pertaining to, characterized by, or promoting sweating, e.g. procedure or an agent that promotes sweating.
Watery bowel movements.
Pain or discomfort with mastication, a symptom of underlying disease. Causes can include problems with the teeth, jaws or temporomandibular joint, mumps, cancer, or a neuromuscular disorder.
Any physical or mental impairment that interferes with an individual's ability to perform desired activities.
The leakage of a substance from an orifice or wound.
A feeling of mental or physical uneasiness, pain, or distress.
Permanent deformation of appearance.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A disorder characterized by reduction in the elements involved in blood coagulation due to their utilization in widespread blood clotting within the vessels.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A pathological process where the blood starts to coagulate throughout the whole body. This depletes the body of its platelets and coagulation factors, and there is an increased risk of hemorrhage.
The condition of being stretched beyond normal dimensions.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
A sensation of lightheadedness, unsteadiness, turning, spinning or rocking.

A syndrome characterized by dryness of the cornea and conjunctiva. It is usually caused by a deficiency in tear production. Symptoms include a feeling of burning eyes and a possible foreign body presence in the eye.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Difficulty moving; distortion or impairment of voluntary movement, as in tic, spasm, or myoclonus.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormality or impairment of voluntary movement.

A symptom referring to difficulty in swallowing. It may be observed in patients with stroke, motor neuron disorders, cancer of the throat or mouth, head and neck injuries, Parkinson disease, and multiple sclerosis.
Impairment of verbal communication skills, often resulting from brain damage.
An uncomfortable sensation of difficulty breathing. It may present as an acute or chronic sign of an underlying respiratory or heart disorder.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Difficulty or pain in urination.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Pain or discomfort during urination.
A flat discoloration of the skin or a mucous membrane, larger in area than a petechia, caused by the extravasation of blood.
Accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in cells or intercellular tissues.
Accumulation of intraretinal fluid and protein in the macula, which may result in swelling and decreased central vision.

Corneal edema of inflammatory origin associated with contact lens wear and morphologically characterized by presence of epithelial microcysts. Microcysts are small (typically 10-50 microns in diameter), clear, irregularly shaped high refractive inclusions that form in the basal layers of the epithelium and move towards the anterior surface of the cornea, surrounding epithelial haze. The cause of microcytic edema is related to the physical presence of contact lenses and possibly a mechanical effect of lens wear.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Fluid from the aqueous humor enters the corneal stroma and causes swelling.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Fluid from the aqueous humor enters the corneal stroma and causes swelling.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Changes in cardiac electrical activity.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding of a change in cardiac electrical activity.
A brief, unintentional exposure to an electric current, which may result in local tissue damage due to thermal injury or in a cardiac dysrhythmia.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The passage of electrical current through the body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The passage of electrical current through the body.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Higher or lower than normal values for the serum electrolytes; usually affecting NA, K, CHL, CO2, glucose, bun.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Higher or lower than normal values for the serum electrolytes; usually affecting NA, K, CHL, CO2, glucose, bun.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Continued electrical rhythmicity of the heart in the absence of effective mechanical function.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding of the presence of cardiac electrical rhythm without a proper response of the myocardial tissue and mechanical cardiac output.
The blockage of a blood vessel lumen by air or solid material such as blood clot or other tissues (e.g., adipose tissue, cancer cells) that have migrated from another anatomic site.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A mass of clotted blood or other formed elements, such as bubbles of air, calcium fragments, etc. brought by the blood from another vessel and forced into a smaller one, thus obstructing the circulation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A mass of clotted blood or other formed elements, such as bubbles of air, calcium fragments, etc. brought by the blood from another vessel and forced into a smaller one, thus obstructing the circulation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A condition of the lung characterized by increase beyond normal in the size of air spaces distal to the terminal bronchioles, either from dilatation of the alveoli or from destruction of their walls.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A subcategory of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It occurs in people who smoke and suffer from chronic bronchitis. It is characterized by inflation of the alveoli, alveolar wall damage, and reduction in the number of alveoli, resulting in difficulty breathing.
An inflammatory process affecting the brain parenchyma. Causes include viral infections and less frequently bacterial infections, toxins, and immune-mediated processes.
A functional and/or structural disorder of the brain caused by diseases (e.g. liver disease, kidney disease), medications, chemicals, and injuries.
Inflammation of the endocardium.
An infectious process affecting the internal structures of the eye.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An eating away or breakdown of any type of external or internal human tissue including but not limited to skin, teeth, mucosa, or somatic, which involves only the outer tissue layer. When tissue surrounds an implanted device, the tissue breakdown may result in migration and loss of the implant material and may result in further complications such as infection or abscess.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An eating away or breakdown of any type of external or internal human tissue including but not limited to skin, teeth, mucosa, or somatic, which involves only the outer tissue layer. When tissue surrounds an implanted device, the tissue breakdown may result in migration and loss of the implant material and may result in further complications such as infection or abscess.

CodeItem.fda_definition: To belch, the casting of upwind from the stomach.
CodeItem.nci_definition: To belch, the casting of upwind from the stomach.
Red discoloration of the skin caused by infectious agents, inflammation, drug hypersensitivity, or underlying disease.
A torn, ragged, mangled wound, or an accidental cut of esophagus.

The presence of a hole or other type of opening in the esophageal wall through which the contents of the esophagus can pass into the mediastinum. The most common cause of esophageal perforation is injury during a medical procedure such as esophagoscopy or placement of a naso-gastric tube; and pathologic process such as neoplasm or gastric reflux with ulceration. Less common causes include injuries from penetrating or blunt trauma or injury to the esophagus during an operation on another organ, mechanical problem such as violent retching or vomiting; ingestion of a foreign body or caustic agents. The condition often results in infection of the mediastinum and mediastinitis.

An electrocardiographic finding in which impaired conduction or automaticity within the sinus node results in the failure of impulse transmission from the sinoatrial node. This is manifested as dropped P waves during sinus rhythm. (CDISC)

CodeItem.fda_definition: Extensive loss of blood due to internal or external hemorrhage.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Extensive loss of blood due to internal or external hemorrhage.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A discharge or escape, as of blood, from a vessel into the tissues.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The leakage of body fluid or cells from the vascular system to the surrounding tissues. This process occurs either by force or as a result of a pathologic reaction (e.g., inflammation). This process may sometimes allow cancer cells to migrate from capillaries to adjacent tissues, initiating micro-metastases.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Extreme fatigue; inability to respond to stimuli.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Extreme fatigue; inability to respond to stimuli.
The removal of a previously inserted tube from a hollow organ or passageway, often from the airway.
Damage to the eye.
Partial or complete paralysis of the facial muscles of one side of a person's face. It is caused by damage to the seventh cranial nerve. It is usually temporary but it may recur.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Extremely weak; threatened with syncope.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Extremely weak; threatened with syncope.
A sudden movement downward, usually resulting in injury.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inflammation of fascia.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammation process in fascia.
Overall tiredness and lack of energy.

Signs or symptoms which may be indicative of distress to a fetus, which may include repetitive variable decelerations, fetal tachycardia or bradycardia, late decelerations, or low biophysical profile.
Elevation of body temperature above normal due to inflammatory or immune responses.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inflammation and fibrous degeneration of a muscle.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammation and fibrous degeneration of a muscle.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The formation of fibrous tissue; fibroid or fibrous degeneration.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The formation of fibrous tissue.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A symptom complex characterized by nervousness, chest pain, back pain, palpations, pruritus, and other usually mild symptoms occurring minutes following the initiation of dialysis with a new dialyzer.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A symptom complex characterized by nervousness, chest pain, back pain, palpations, pruritus, and other usually mild symptoms occurring minutes following the initiation of dialysis with a new dialyzer.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A burn that only affects the outer layer of skin causing pain, redness, and swelling.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A painful injury to the epidermis due to chemical, friction, radiation or thermal exposure. The affected area appears red and blanches when touched.
Abnormal epithelial-lined communication between two anatomical structures.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A sudden or brief burst of light.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The perception of sudden or brief bursts (flashes) of light.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Gas or air in the gastrointestinal tract.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Gas or air in the gastrointestinal tract.
The pouring forth of a fluid.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A decrease in the fraction of the forced vital capacity that is exhaled in a specific number of seconds.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A decrease in the fraction of the forced vital capacity that is exhaled in a specific number of seconds.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An increase in the fraction of the forced vital capacity that is exhaled in a specific number of seconds.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An increase in the fraction of the forced vital capacity that is exhaled in a specific number of seconds.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An occurrence where any object originating inside or outside the body is not in it's physiological or intended location. For example, a tooth or bone fragment being swallowed; or device's components or fragments being found in the body away from where they were implanted.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Extraneous material within the body.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A granulomatous inflammatory reaction evoked by the presence of an exogenous material in the tissues, a characteristic feature of which is the formation of foreign body giant cells.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A granulomatous inflammatory reaction evoked by the presence of an exogenous material in the tissues, a characteristic feature of which is the formation of foreign body giant cells.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Feeling of grittiness or having something in the eye; frequently caused by a foreign body. Other possible causes include corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, inturned eye lash or acute conjunctivitis.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Feeling of grittiness or having something in the eye; frequently caused by a foreign body. Other possible causes include corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, inturned eye lash or acute conjunctivitis.
A traumatic injury to the bone in which the continuity of the bone is broken.
A traumatic break in one or more of the bones in the arm or forearm.
A bone fracture that is taking an abnormally long time to heal.

Traumatic or pathological injury to the hip in which the continuity of either the femoral head, femoral neck, intertrochanteric or subtrochanteric regions is broken. Symptoms include pain in the hip or groin, bruising and swelling in and around the hip area. The injured hip is turned outward and the leg appears shorter on that side.
A traumatic or pathologic injury to the bones of the skull in which the continuity of the bones of the skull is broken.

Broken tooth affecting any portion of tooth: root fracture, crown-root, broken tooth (crown fracture), chipped tooth. A crown fracture can involve the pulp. Tooth fracture sequelae range in severity from cosmetic defects to tooth death. Involvement of the pulp is a more important indicator of severity of tooth fracture than is the amount of the tooth affected.

A kingdom of eukaryotic, heterotrophic organisms that live as saprobes or parasites, including mushrooms, yeasts, smuts, molds, etc. They reproduce either sexually or asexually, and have life cycles that range from simple to complex. Filamentous fungi refer to those that grow as multicellular colonies (mushrooms and molds).

CodeItem.fda_definition: Death of tissue, usually in considerable mass and generally associated with loss of vascular (nutritive) supply and followed by bacterial invasion and putrefaction.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Death of tissue, usually in considerable mass and generally associated with loss of vascular (nutritive) supply and followed by bacterial invasion and putrefaction.
Inflammation of the stomach.
Increased pressure in the eyeball due to obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor.
An inflammatory reaction usually caused by infectious organisms, foreign bodies, or cholesterol deposits. It is characterized by the presence of epithelioid histiocytes and chronic inflammation.

Hair loss usually from the scalp. It may result in bald spots or spread to the entire scalp or the entire epidermis. It may be androgenetic or caused by chemotherapeutic agents, compulsive hair pulling, autoimmune disorders or congenital conditions.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Hazy ring around bright lights seen by some patients with refractive error or optical defects, e.g. cataracts, or corneal swelling.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Hazy ring around bright lights seen by some patients with refractive error or optical defects, e.g. cataracts, or corneal swelling.
A traumatic injury to the head.
Pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Headache in erect position, after lumbar puncture; due to lowering of intracranial pressure by leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the needle tract.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Headache in erect position, after lumbar puncture; due to lowering of intracranial pressure by leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the needle tract.
Improper body tissue repair due to factors affecting one or more of the phases of wound healing, including hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling.

Partial or complete loss of the ability to detect or understand sounds resulting from damage to the outer, middle, or inner ear structures. Causes include exposure to loud noise, ear infections, injuries to the ear, genetic, and congenital disorders.
A partial or complete loss of hearing in one or both ears. It is classified as conductive, sensory, or central.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inability of the heart to pump blood at an adequate rate to fill tissue metabolic requirements or the ability to do so only at an elevated filling pressure.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inability of the heart to pump blood at an adequate rate to meet tissue metabolic requirements. Clinical symptoms of heart failure include: unusual dyspnea on light exertion, recurrent dyspnea occurring in the supine position, fluid retention or rales, jugular venous distension, pulmonary edema on physical exam, or pulmonary edema on chest x-ray presumed to be cardiac dysfunction.
Abdominal discomfort with retrosternal pain usually associated with gastroesophageal reflux..

CodeItem.fda_definition: A localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A localized collection of blood, usually clotted, in an organ, space, or tissue, due to a break in the wall of a blood vessel.
Blood in the urine.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An increase in the concentration of blood cells resulting from the loss of plasma or water from the blood stream.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An increase in the concentration of blood cells resulting from the loss of plasma or water from the blood stream.
Disruption of the integrity of the erythrocyte membrane causing release of hemoglobin.
Anemia resulting from the premature destruction of the peripheral blood red cells. It may be congenital or it may be caused by infections, medications, or malignancies.
Coughing up blood from the respiratory tract.
The flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Hemorrhage into the cerebrum. See also Stroke Syndrome.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Bleeding within the cerebrum.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Intracranial hemorrhage into the epidural space.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Intracranial hemorrhage into the epidural space.
Bleeding into the brain's ventricles.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Intracranial hemorrhage into the subarachnoid space.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Intracranial hemorrhage into the subarachnoid space.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Cerebral hemorrhage into the subdural space. See also Stroke Syndrome.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Bleeding between the dura mater and the brain, usually secondary to a tear of the bridging vein.
Bleeding between the scalp and the periosteum.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The arrest of bleeding, either by the physiological properties of vasoconstriction and coagulation or by surgical means.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The arrest of bleeding, either by the natural processes of vasoconstriction and coagulation or by surgical means.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A collection of blood in the pleural cavity.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A collection of blood in the pleural cavity.
Inflammation of the liver; usually from a viral infection, but sometimes from toxic agents.
The protrusion of part of an organ or fibroadipose tissue through an abnormal opening.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Any inflammatory skin disease caused by a herpesvirus and characterized by the formation of small vesicles in clusters.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Any inflammatory skin disease caused by a herpesvirus and characterized by the formation of small vesicles in clusters.
An involuntary contraction of the diaphragm against closed vocal cords, producing the "hic" sound.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A cytopathic retrovirus. It is the etiological agent of AIDS.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The virus isolated and recognized as the etiologic agent of AIDS. HIV-1 is classified as a lentivirus, a subtype of retroviruses.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Growth of tissue in or around a foreign body as the body's antibody response to the foreign body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Growth of tissue in or around a foreign body as the body's antibody response to the foreign body.

A temporary feeling of intense body warmth, flushing, sometimes accompanied by sweating. A common, symptom of menopause; other conditions that can produce hot flushes include antidepressants and drugs blocking the effect of estrogens, carcinoid tumors and a sensitivity to sulfites or other food additives.
A disorder characterized by an abnormal increase of cerebrospinal fluid in the ventricles of the brain.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Excessive concentrations of bilirubin in the blood, which may lead to jaundice.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormally high level of bilirubin in the blood. Excess bilirubin is associated with jaundice.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The presence of an increased amount of blood in a part or organ; engorgement.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The presence of an increased amount of blood in a part or organ; engorgement.
Abnormally high level of glucose in the blood.
Higher than normal levels of sodium in the circulating blood.
An abnormal increase in the number of cells in an organ or a tissue with consequent enlargement.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Hypersensitivity; a local or general reaction of an organism following contact with a specific allergen to which it has been previously exposed and to which it has become sensitized.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An immune response that occurs following exposure to an innocuous antigen, but that does not require the presence of preformed antibodies to the antigen.
Blood pressure that is abnormally high.

A condition characterized by an abnormally high body temperature. In a hyperthermic state, the hypothalamic set-point is normal but body temperature increases and overrides the ability to lose heat, resulting from exogenous heat exposure or endogenous heat production.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Abnormally prolonged, rapid, and deep breathing.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormally prolonged, rapid, and deep breathing.
Too much fluid in the blood.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Hemorrhage within the anterior chamber of the eye; bloodshot.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Hemorrhage within the anterior chamber of the eye; bloodshot.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Consisting of abnormally decreased sensitivity, particularly to touch.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Impairment of tactile sensitivity manifesting as partial loss of sensitivity to sensory stimuli.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Consisting of abnormally decreased sensitivity, particularly to touch.
Consisting of abnormally decreased sensitivity, particularly to touch.

CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormally low level of glucose in the blood.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber of the eye.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber of the eye.
Blood pressure that is abnormally low.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Abnormally low body temperature.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormally low body temperature.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A state in which there is a reduced amount of air entering the pulmonary alveoli.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A state in which there is a reduced amount of air entering the pulmonary alveoli.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Abnormally decreased volume of circulating fluid (plasma) in body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormally decreased volume of circulating fluid (plasma) in body.
A decrease in the amount of oxygen in the body. Symptoms range from mild (impaired judgment, memory loss, impaired motor coordination) to severe (seizures and coma).

CodeItem.fda_definition: Caused by conditions such as inadequate placental function (often abruptio placentae), preeclamptic toxicity, prolapse of the umbilical cord, or complications from anesthetic administration.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Hypoxia in utero, caused by conditions such as inadequate placental function (often abruptio placentae), preeclamptic toxicity, prolapse of the umbilical cord, or complications from anesthetic administration.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Relating to or affecting the cardiac ventricles alone.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding of three or more consecutive complexes of ventricular origin with a rate less than a certain threshold (100 or 120 beats per minute are commonly used). The QRS complexes are wide and have an abnormal morphology. (CDISC)

CodeItem.fda_definition: A deficiency of immune response or a disorder characterized by deficient immune response.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Syndromes in which there is a deficiency or defect in the mechanisms of immunity, either cellular or humoral.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An object or material, such as an alloplastic or radioactive material or tissue, partially or totally inserted or grafted into the body for prosthetic, therapeutic, diagnostic, or experimental purposes.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Malfunction of a medical implant.
Persistent or recurrent inability to achieve or to maintain an erection during sexual activity.
Insufficient structural and functional connection between living bone and the surface of a synthetic implant.

CodeItem.fda_definition: One that is abnormally prone to dilate in the second trimester of pregnancy, resulting in premature expulsion of the fetus.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A clinical diagnosis presenting with painless cervical dilatation and spontaneous mid-trimester birth in recurrent pregnancies in the absence of spontaneous membrane rupture, bleeding or clinical chorioamnionitis.
Involuntary passage of stool or urine from the body.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An ischemic condition of the brain, producing a persistent focal neurological deficit in the area of distribution of the cerebral arteries.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An ischemic condition of the brain, producing a persistent focal neurological deficit in the area of distribution of the cerebral arteries.
A disorder resulting from the presence and activity of a microbial, viral, fungal, or parasitic agent. It can be transmitted by direct or indirect contact.
An acute infectious disorder that is caused by gram positive or gram negative bacteria; representative examples include pneumococcal, streptococcal, salmonella, and meningeal infections.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Infection produced by direct contact with another person.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Infection produced by direct contact with another person.
An infection caused by a fungus.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Infection transmitted by water, food or other means of conveyance.
Infection within the eye.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Infection within the eye.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An infection caused by pus-producing organisms.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An infection caused by pus-producing organisms.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Infection associated with no detectable symptoms but caused by microorganisms capable of producing easily recognizable diseases, such a poliomyelitis or mumps.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Infection associated with no detectable symptoms but caused by microorganisms capable of producing easily recognizable diseases, such a poliomyelitis or mumps.
An infectious process affecting the upper respiratory tract (nose, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, or trachea). Symptoms include congestion, sneezing, coughing, fever, and sore throat.

A bacterial infectious process affecting any part of the urinary tract, most commonly the bladder and the urethra. Symptoms include urinary urgency and frequency, burning sensation during urination, lower abdominal discomfort, and cloudy urine.
Any disease caused by a virus.

CodeItem.fda_definition: To penetrate a tissue or substance.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The process of the diffusion or accumulation in a tissue or cells of a substance not normal to it or in amounts above normal. (NCI)

A localized protective response resulting from injury or destruction of tissues. Inflammation serves to destroy, dilute, or wall off both the injurious agent and the injured tissue. In the acute phase, inflammation is characterized by the signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function. Histologically, inflammation involves a complex series of events, including dilatation of arterioles, capillaries, and venules, with increased permeability and blood flow; exudation of fluids, including plasma proteins; and leukocyte migration into the site of inflammation.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Dysfunction of one of the cardiac valves, with incomplete valve closure resulting in valvular regurgitation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Dysfunction of one of the cardiac valves characterized by incomplete valve closure.
Uterine bleeding that occurs during a time not associated with the normal menstrual period.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Pertaining to the inner layer of the blood vessels.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A dissection of an artery that occurs though a tear in the inner lining of the blood vessel.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Bleeding within the cranium.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Bleeding within the cranium.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Increase of pressure of the intraocular fluid in the eye.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Increased pressure of the intraocular fluid in the eye.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Changes in the fluid pressure inside the eye.
Inflammation of the iris.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammation of the iris.
Excited response to stimuli.
A mild inflammatory tissue reaction; it can be caused by physical contact with an irritant or can be a local response to a systemic trigger.
Lack of blood supply to an area of the body, resulting in impairment of tissue oxygenation.

A disorder of cardiac function caused by insufficient blood flow to the muscle tissue of the heart. The decreased blood flow may be due to narrowing of the coronary arteries, to obstruction by a thrombus, or less commonly, to diffuse narrowing of arterioles and other small vessels within the heart. Severe interruption of the blood supply to the myocardial tissue may result in necrosis of cardiac muscle (myocardial infarction).
An intense itching sensation.
Yellow pigmentation of the skin, mucous membranes, and the eyes due to hyperbilirubinemia. Causes include liver disease, biliary tract obstruction, and hemolysis.
An abnormal separation where two or more bones meet.
Any disorder of the joints.
The presence of swelling in a joint.
Inflammation of the cornea.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Keratitis due to infection by acanthamoeba; it is usually associated with soft contact lens wear, particularly overnight wear.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Keratitis due to infection by acanthamoeba; it is usually associated with soft contact lens wear, particularly overnight wear.
Regular uterine activity with associated cervical change prior to 37 weeks gestation.
A cut or tear in any tissue.
Impairment of the left ventricle to either fill or eject adequately.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Failure of adequate output by the left ventricle despite an increase in distending pressure and in end-diastolic volume, with dyspnea, orthopnea, and other signs and symptoms of pulmonary congestion and edema.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Failure of adequate output by the left ventricle despite an increase in distending pressure and in end-diastolic volume, with dyspnea, orthopnea, and other signs and symptoms of pulmonary congestion and edema.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Enlargement or overgrowth of the myocardium of the left ventricle, due to chronic pressure overload.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Enlargement or overgrowth of the myocardium of the left ventricle, due to chronic pressure overload.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
An injury to any of the fibrous bands of tissue that comprise an articulation (joint).

CodeItem.fda_pt: Limited Mobility Of The Implanted Joint

CodeItem.fda_definition: Bruising of the liver.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Bruising of the liver.
A finding that indicates abnormal liver function.
A cut or tear in the liver.
An inability to purposefully respond to stimuli.
A below normal volume of blood pumped from the right or left ventricle of the heart per unit time.
Abnormal permanent enlargement of the lung air spaces distal to terminal bronchiole not resulted from wall destruction, e.g. due to loss of opposite lung.

An autoimmune, connective tissue chronic inflammatory disorder affecting the skin, joints, kidneys, lungs, heart, and the peripheral blood cells. It is more commonly seen in women than men. Variants include discoid and systemic lupus erythematosus.

A malignant (clonal) proliferation of B- lymphocytes or T- lymphocytes which involves the lymph nodes, bone marrow and/or extranodal sites. This category includes Non-Hodgkin lymphomas and Hodgkin lymphomas.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.

A radiologic finding indicating the presence of abnormalities in the breast parenchyma identified in a mammogram performed for screening or diagnostic purposes. These abnormalities include calcifications, breast tissue distortion, presence of areas of density, and presence of benign or malignant tumors.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Normal location of the mediastinum changes to the right or left, depending upon the underlying cause.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Displacement of structures in the thoracic cavity in one direction due to increased pleural pressure on the contralateral side.
Systematic and extensive loss of memory caused by organic or psychological factors. The loss may be temporary or permanent, and may involve old or recent memories.
A disorder characterized by acute inflammation of the meninges of the brain and/or spinal cord.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Deviations from the normal process; e.g. delayed, difficult, profuse, scanty, unusual bleeding, etc.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Deviations from the normal process; e.g. delayed, difficult, profuse, scanty, unusual bleeding, etc.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Very small, round vesicles containing fluid and cellular debris observed on the surface of the cornea under slit-lamp examination in some types of corneal dystrophy and in wearers of extended-wear lenses.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Very small, round vesicles containing fluid and cellular debris observed on the surface of the cornea under slit-lamp examination in some types of corneal dystrophy and in wearers of extended-wear lenses.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A sudden compelling urge to urinate.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An acute and compelling urge to urinate.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Loss of the products of conception from the uterus before the fetus is viable; spontaneous abortion.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Fetal loss at less than 20 weeks of gestation.
A dose of medicine that was not taken at the prescribed dosing interval.

A specific reason explaining why a meaningful value is not available. A meaningful value answers the question posed by a Data Element Concept. In contrast, a Missing Value Reason answers the implicit question "Why is there no 'meaningful' value?", when there is none.
Dysfunction of the mitral valve characterized by incomplete valve closure.
A rupture in the mitral valve tissue due to traumatic or pathologic processes.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium, owing to insufficiency of the mitral valve; it may be acute or chronic, usually due to mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic heart disease or a complication of cardiac dilatation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium, owing to insufficiency of the mitral valve; it may be acute or chronic, usually due to mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic heart disease or a complication of cardiac dilatation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Narrowing of the left atrioventricular mitral orifice.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Narrowing of the left atrioventricular mitral orifice.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Prolapse of the mitral valve, often with regurgitation, associated with myxomatous proliferation of the leaflets of the mitral valve.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A fairly common and often benign valvular heart disorder characterized by redundancy or hooding of mitral valve leaflets so that they prolapse into the left atrium, often causing mitral regurgitation. It is often a symptomless condition but may be marked by varied symptoms (e.g. chest pain, fatigue, dizziness, dyspnea, or palpitations) leading in some cases to endocarditis or ventricular tachycardia.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A progressive condition usually characterized by combined failure of the lungs, liver, kidney, and clotting mechanisms.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Complete impairment of two or more organs or organ systems.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A sudden, violent, involuntary contraction of a muscle or group of muscles.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A sudden, violent, involuntary contraction of a muscle or group of muscles.
A reduction in the strength of one or more muscles.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Stiffness or inflexibility.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An involuntary, persistent state of firm, tense muscles with marked resistance to passive movement.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An involuntary, compulsive, repetitive stereotyped movement, usually of the face or shoulders.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An involuntary, compulsive, repetitive stereotyped movement, usually of the face or shoulders.
Painful sensation originating from a muscle or group of muscles.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A bruise to the heart.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A bruise to the heart.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.
Inflammation of the muscle tissue of the heart.
Blockage of the nasal passages.
Upper abdominal discomfort associated with an urge to vomit.
A cell death process that is morphologically characterized by a gain in cell volume (oncosis), swelling of organelles, plasma membrane rupture and subsequent loss of intracellular contents.
A penetrating stab wound from a needle (or other sharp object) that may result in exposure to blood or other body fluids.
A congenital anatomic abnormality manifested during the neonatal period.
An abnormality that affects hearing within the first month after birth. It may or may not result in hearing loss.
Partial or complete loss of the ability to detect or understand sounds present in an infant within its first month after birth.

The formation of new or recent blood vessels. The vasculature network is critical to the development of neoplasms. As the tumor burden grows, vascular endothelial cells are recruited to form new blood vessels as an increased demand for blood and nourishment is required.
Injury to nervous tissue.
Injury in the central or peripheral nervous system.
A finding of pathologic function within the central or peripheral nervous system, secondary to developmental abnormalities, infections, neurologic damage, or tumors.

A disorder affecting the cranial nerves or the peripheral nervous system. It manifests with pain, tingling, numbness, and muscle weakness. It may be the result of physical injury, toxic substances, viral diseases, diabetes, renal failure, cancer, and drugs.
Ulcer that develops in the nipple. Causes include trauma and Paget disease.

CodeItem.fda_pt: No Consequences Or Impact To Patient
CodeItem.fda_synonym: Consequences Or Impact To Patient, None
Impact Or Consequences To Patient, None
Patient, No Consequences Or Impact To

CodeItem.nci_definition: Information regarding the subject is unknown or inaccessible at this time.

CodeItem.fda_pt: No Known Impact Or Consequence To Patient

CodeItem.fda_definition: If a value for test has to be provided, but has no given criteria (e.g., the result is for "report only" or "monitoring").
CodeItem.nci_definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.
A loss of the sensation of feeling in an area of the body.
Blockage of the normal flow of the contents of an anatomical passageway.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The act of closure or the state of being closed; an obstruction; the relationship between all of the components of the masticatory system in normal function, dysfunction, and parafunction; momentary complete closure of some area in the vocal tract, causing stoppage of the breath and accumulation of pressure.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Obstruction or a closure of hollow organ, passageway or vessel; also the transient approximation of the edges of a natural opening; imperforation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The formation of bone or of a bony substance; the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The formation of bone or of a bony substance; the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Dissolution of bone; applied especially to the removal or loss of the calcium of bone.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Dissolution of bone; applied especially to the removal or loss of the calcium of bone.
Decreased calcification or density of bone tissue.
Exposure to, or intake of, an excessive amount of a substance.
A level of sedation that is greater than the intended level.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Ocular pain which may be very intense, accompanied by corneal epithelium damage, conjunctival injection, lacrimation, blepharospasm, photophobia and hazy vision following corneal edema caused by overwear of contact lenses, principally the PMMA type.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Ocular pain which may be very intense, accompanied by corneal epithelium damage, conjunctival injection, lacrimation, blepharospasm, photophobia and hazy vision following corneal edema caused by overwear of contact lenses, principally the PMMA type.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The calculated measurements indicating the degree to which oxygen is bound to hemoglobin is high.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A high level of the degree to which oxygen is bound to hemoglobin given as a percentage calculated by dividing the maximum oxygen capacity into the actual oxygen content and multiplying by 100. Oxygen saturation usually is measured using pulse oximetry.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The calculated measurements indicating the degree to which oxygen is bound to hemoglobin is low.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A low level of the degree to which oxygen is bound to hemoglobin given as a percentage calculated by dividing the maximum oxygen capacity into the actual oxygen content and multiplying by 100. Oxygen saturation usually is measured using pulse oximetry.
The sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony, resulting from the stimulation of specialized nerve endings.
Painful sensation in the abdominal region.
Painful sensation in the neck area.
An unusual or extreme paleness, state of decreased skin or mucosal coloration.
An unpleasant sensation of irregular and/or forceful beating of the heart.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Superficial vascularization of the cornea with infiltration of granulation tissue; an inflammatory exudate overlying the lining layer of synovial cells on the inside of a joint.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Superficial vascularization of the cornea with infiltration of granulation tissue; an inflammatory exudate overlying the lining layer of synovial cells on the inside of a joint.
Partial or complete loss of function of one or more muscles. It is usually caused by damage to the nervous system.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Paralysis of the legs and lower part of the body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Complete paralysis of the lower half of the body including both legs, often caused by damage to the spinal cord.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A slight or incomplete paralysis.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A slight or incomplete paralysis.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A decrease of the greatest rate of flow that can be achieved during forced expiration beginning with the lungs fully inflated.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Decreased expiratory peak flow measurement achieved during forced expiration that primarily reflects changes in upper airway conductance and may be of limited use in evaluation of changes in peripheral airway conductance. Evaluation of peak flow performance is subjective, and, therefore, acceptability criteria are lacking. Because the maneuver is effort and volume dependent, the patient must be encouraged to perform as vigorously as clinically feasible. The results of subjective evaluation may be difficult to interpret consistently. A validated dyspnea rating scale may be useful.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An increase of the greatest rate of flow that can be achieved during forced expiration beginning with the lungs fully inflated.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An increase of the greatest rate of flow that can be achieved during forced expiration beginning with the lungs fully inflated.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A peeling off or loss of epidermis, as in sunburn, postscarlatinal peeling, or toxic epidermal necrolysis.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A peeling off or loss of epidermis, as in sunburn, postscarlatinal peeling, or toxic epidermal necrolysis.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Any pelvic infection involving the upper female genital tract beyond the cervix.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an acute or chronic inflammation in the pelvic cavity. It is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted diseases, including chlamydia and gonorrhea that have ascended into the uterus, fallopian tubes, or ovaries as a result of intercourse or childbirth, or of surgical procedures, including insertion of IUDs or abortion. PID may be either symptomatic or asymptomatic. It may cause infertility and it may raise the risk of ectopic pregnancy. PID is a disease associated with HIV infection.
A hole or opening made through a membrane or other tissue or material.
Fluid collection within the pericardial sac, usually due to inflammation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Injury occurring as a result of the delivery process.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Injury to the brain of a newborn infant occurring around the time of birth.
Any disorder affecting blood flow through the veins or arteries outside of the heart.
A cut or tear of the peritoneum.

Inflammation of the peritoneum due to infection by bacteria or fungi. Causes include liver disease, perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or biliary tract, and peritoneal dialysis. Patients usually present with abdominal pain and tenderness, fever, chills, and nausea and vomiting. It is an emergency medical condition that requires prompt medical attention and treatment.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Paralysis of the nerves located in the legs.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Paralysis of the nerves located in the legs.
Inflammation of the throat most often caused by viral and bacterial infections. Other causes include allergens, chemical substances, and trauma.
Inflammation of a vein.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An objective visual sensation that appears with the eyes closed and in the absence of visual light.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An objective visual sensation that appears with the eyes closed and in the absence of visual light.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A nonimmunologic, chemically induced type of photosensitivity.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A nonimmunologic, chemically induced type of photosensitivity.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Patient becomes entangled or caught in a bed, particularly in side rails, or mattress, or head/foot boards.

CodeItem.nci_definition: Having different forms at different stages of the life cycle.

Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

An acute, acute and chronic, or chronic inflammation focally or diffusely affecting the lung parenchyma, due to infections (viruses, fungi, mycoplasma, or bacteria), treatment (e.g. radiation), or exposure (inhalation) to chemicals. Symptoms include cough, shortness of breath, fevers, chills, chest pain, headache, sweating, and weakness.
Abnormal presence of air in the pleural cavity.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Erosion of patient's skin pocket which houses a device.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Erosion of patient's skin pocket which houses a device.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Chronic excessive intake of water; it may be from an organic cause, such as the dehydration of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, or a reaction to medication, or from a psychological cause. When untreated it can lead to water intoxication.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Chronic excessive intake of water; it may be from an organic cause, such as the dehydration of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, or a reaction to medication, or from a psychological cause. When untreated it can lead to water intoxication.
An idiopathic inflammatory disorder affecting the muscles. It presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and elevated skeletal muscle enzymes.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Antibodies directed against nuclear antigens; almost invariably found in systemic lupus erythematosus and are frequently found in rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, Sjogren's Syndrome and mixed connective tissue disease.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Indicates that antibodies directed against nuclear antigens have been detected.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The state or condition of having a developing embryo or fetus in the body (uterus), after union of an ovum and spermatozoon, during the period from conception to birth.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The state or condition of having a developing embryo or fetus in the body (uterus), after union of an ovum and spermatozoon, during the period from conception to birth.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The state or condition of having a developing embryo or fetus in the body (outside the uterus), after union of an ovum and spermatozoon, during the period from conception to birth.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An abnormal pregnancy in which the conception is implanted outside the endometrial cavity.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Death of tissue due to external pressure.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Death of tissue due to external pressure.
A condition in which an organ or body tissue drops or bulges out of place.

The creation of hematoma outside the arterial wall following bleeding due to puncture of the arterial wall. Pseudoaneurysms can also occur in the heart chambers following myocardial infarction and bleeding.
The drooping of the upper eyelid.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The measurement of the mean left arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is high.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The measurement of the mean left arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is high.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The measurement of the mean left pulmonary arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is low.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The measurement of the mean left pulmonary arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is low.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The measurement of the mean left arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is normal.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The measurement of the mean left arterial pressure, as measured by a catheter introduced into the distal pulmonary artery, is normal.

Accumulation of fluid in the lung tissues causing disturbance of the gas exchange that may lead to respiratory failure. It is caused by direct injury to the lung parenchyma or congestive heart failure. The symptoms may appear suddenly or gradually. Suddenly appearing symptoms include difficulty breathing, feeling of suffocation, and coughing associated with frothy sputum. Gradually appearing symptoms include difficulty breathing while lying in bed, shortness of breath during activity, and weight gain (in patients with congestive heart failure).

CodeItem.fda_definition: The closure of the pulmonary artery or one of its branches by an embolus, sometimes associated with infarction of the lung.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The obstruction of the pulmonary artery or one of its branches by an embolus, sometimes associated with infarction of the lung.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Localized necrosis of lung tissue caused by obstruction of the arterial blood supply, most often due to pulmonary embolism.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Localized necrosis of lung tissue caused by obstruction of the arterial blood supply, most often due to pulmonary embolism.

Impairment of gas exchange within the lungs secondary to a disease process, neoplasm, or trauma, possibly resulting in hypoxia, hypercarbia, or both, but not requiring intubation or mechanical ventilation. Patients are normally managed with pharmaceutical therapy, supplemental oxygen, or both.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle, owing to insufficiency of the pulmonic semilunar valve.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle, owing to insufficiency of the pulmonic semilunar valve.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Narrowing of the opening between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle, usually at the level of the valve leaflets.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Narrowing of the opening between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle, usually at the level of the valve leaflets.
Weak or absent palpable pulse due to decreased arterial pulse pressure.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A pulse that beats at irregular intervals.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Not rhythmic pulse irregular in beat or accent.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An obstruction of the pupil.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An obstruction of the pupil.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Consisting of or containing pus; associated with the formation of or caused by pus.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Pus-containing fluid that is draining from an orifice or wound.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Paralysis of all four limbs.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Paralysis of all four limbs.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The occurrence of a premature ventricular complex near the peak of the T wave in electrocardiography; it may lead to ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding in which the R wave of a premature ventricular complex occurs on top of the T wave of the preceding beat. (CDISC)

CodeItem.fda_definition: A burn caused by exposure to x-ray, radium, sunlight, atomic or any other type of radiant energy.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A burn caused by exposure to x-ray, radium, sunlight, atomic or any other type of radiant energy.
A higher than intended cumulative dose of radiation to a single field.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Radiation induced skin desquamation
CodeItem.nci_definition: The complex of symptoms characterizing the disease known as radiation injury, resulting from excessive exposure (greater than 200 rads or 2 gray) of the whole body (or large part) to ionizing radiation. The earliest of these symptoms are nausea, fatigue, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be followed by epilation, hemorrhage, inflammation of the mouth and throat, and general loss of energy. In severe cases, where the radiation exposure has been approximately 1000 Rad (10 gray) or more, death may occur within two to four weeks. Those who survive six weeks after the receipt of a single large dose of radiation to the whole body may generally be expected to recover. (U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission).
An inadequate amount of a radiation treatment.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A cutaneous inflammatory reaction occurring as a result of exposure to biologically effective levels of ionizing radiation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A cutaneous inflammatory reaction occurring as a result of exposure to biologically effective levels of ionizing radiation.
A finding that the flexibility of a joint is below the expected range of normal for that individual.

Any change in the skin which affects its appearance or texture. A rash may be localized to one part of the body, or affect all the skin. Rashes may cause the skin to change color, itch, become warm, bumpy, dry, cracked or blistered, swell and may be painful.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Intermittent bilateral attacks of ischemia of the fingers or toes and sometimes of the ears or nose, marked by severe pallor, and often accompanied by paresthesia and pain.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An episodic vasoconstriction resulting in discoloration of the skin and pain in the affected areas, often involving fingers or toes. Classically associated with triphasic color changes (white, blue, red) but may be biphasic. Often occurs in response to cold temperatures or emotional stress. May be primary or secondary to an underlying autoimmune disease.
A response generated by a stimulus.
An intense reaction (usually immunologic) developing at the site of injection
A regionally-limited response to an antigen, which may include inflammation, induration, erythema, pruritus or pain.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Lay term applied to any condition with dilation of conjunctival or ciliary blood vessels; innumerable causes, especially irritation and infection.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Lay term applied to any condition with dilation of conjunctival or ciliary blood vessels; innumerable causes, especially irritation and infection.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Flow in the opposite direction from normal, as the casting up of undigested food or gas from the stomach, or the backward flowing of blood into the heart, or between the chambers of the heart when a valve is incompetent.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Flow in the opposite direction from normal, as the casting up of undigested food or gas from the stomach, or the backward flowing of blood into the heart, or between the chambers of the heart when a valve is incompetent.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Regurgitation of the blood of the heart valves owning to imperfect closing, insufficiency or incompetency of the valves.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Regurgitation of the blood of the heart valves owning to imperfect closing, insufficiency or incompetency of the valves.
The infusion of autogenic body fluid that has previously been withdrawn from the patient.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Chronic, irreversible renal failure.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Long-standing and persistent renal disease with glomerular filtration rate (GFR) less than 15 ml/min.
An acute or chronic condition that is characterized by the inability of the kidneys to adequately filter the blood.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A state due to excess retention of carbon dioxide in the body.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A condition in which the blood pH is less than normal, secondary to impaired gas exchange.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A pathologic condition resulting from accumulation of base, or from loss of acid without comparable loss of base in the body fluids, and characterized by decrease in hydrogen ion concentration.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A condition in which the blood pH is greater than normal, secondary to impaired gas exchange.
A pathological increase in the effort and frequency of breathing movements.

CodeItem.fda_synonym: RDS, Respiratory Distress Syndrome Of Newborns
CodeItem.fda_definition: A condition of the newborn marked by dyspnea with cyanosis, most frequently occurring in premature infants, children of diabetic mothers and infants delivered by cesarean section, and sometimes with no predisposing cause.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A condition beginning in the first day of life that results from inadequate surfactant production, causing increased work of breathing and impaired gas exchange.

The significant impairment of gas exchange within the lungs resulting in hypoxia, hypercarbia, or both, to the extent that organ tissue perfusion is severely compromised. Causes include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, emphysema, acute respiratory distress syndrome, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, pneumothorax, and congestive heart failure. Treatment requires intubation and mechanical ventilation until the time the lungs recover sufficient function.
Abnormal decrease of rate of breathing.
Abnormal increase of rate of breathing.
Injury to the retina due to advanced age, toxicity, exposure to bright lights, or trauma.
Degeneration of the retina.
A usually small tearing of the retina occurring when the vitreous separates from the retina. It may lead to retinal detachment. Symptoms include flashes and floaters.

An autoinflammatory condition following an infection with Group A Beta Hemolytic Streptococcus (GABHS), in which the heart is attacked by antibodies formed in reaction to a recent GABHS infection. Chief anatomic changes of the valve include leaflet thickening, commissural fusion, and shortening and thickening of the tendinous cords, all of which can result in valvular dysfunction.
Impairment of the right ventricular function associated with low ejection fraction and decreased motility of the right ventricular wall.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Failure of proper functioning of the right ventricle, with venous engorgement, hepatic enlargement, and subcutaneous edema.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Failure of proper functioning of the right ventricle, with venous engorgement, hepatic enlargement, and subcutaneous edema.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Enlargement or overgrowth of the myocardium of the right ventricle, due chronic pressure overload.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Enlargement or overgrowth of the myocardium of the right ventricle, due chronic pressure overload.
Forcible tearing or disruption of tissue.
A surgical procedure to reduce the appearance of a scar.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Formation of new tissue formed in the healing of a wound.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Formation of new tissue formed in the healing of a wound.
A permanent mark left on the skin in the process of wound healing.

A localized or systemic chronic and progressive autoimmune disorder characterized by thickening of the skin and the connective tissues. Localized scleroderma affects only the skin. Systemic scleroderma affects internal organs, including the heart, lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A partial thickness burn that affects both the outer and underlying layer of skin causing pain, redness, swelling and blistering.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An injury that includes the entire epidermis and upper layers of the dermis due to a chemical, friction, radiation or thermal exposure. The affected area appears as moist red or white skin that does not blanch. Often it is painful with the presence of blisters.
The process of allaying nervous excitement or the state of being calmed. (Taber's)
Sudden, involuntary skeletal muscular contractions of cerebral or brain stem origin.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The seizure seen in absence epilepsy, consisting of a sudden momentary break in consciousness of thought or activity, often accompanied by automatisms or clonic movements, especially of the eyelids.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Generalized seizure that manifests in a form of a brief episode of impairment of consciousness with or without accompanying motor phenomena such as clonic-tonic components, automatisms, or autonomic components.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Partial seizure.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A transitory alteration in movement, sensation or autonomic nerve function due to abnormal electric activity in a localized area of the cerebral cortex, usually without change in awareness or alertness. Symptoms vary with different lesion locations and may include but not limited to the motor (e.g. rhythmic muscle contractions in one area of the body), somatosensory and sensory alterations manifested by abnormal numbness, paresthesias or other hallucinations, including several types of aura; autonomic and psychic symptoms, e.g. with changes in speech, thought, personality, mood, sensation of deja vu or hallucinations.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A simple partial seizure consisting of clonus or spasm of a muscle or muscle group; it may be single or in a continuous and repetitive series or may spread to adjacent muscles.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A simple partial seizure consisting of clonus or spasm of a muscle or muscle group; it may be single or in a continuous and repetitive series or may spread to adjacent muscles.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A symptomatic form of epilepsy often preceded by an aura; characterized by loss of consciousness with generalized tonic- clonic seizures.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A generalized tonic-clinic seizure, characterized by loss of consciousness. This type of seizure may be preceded by an aura and is frequently followed by a period of confusion and lethargy (post-ictal state).

The presence of pathogenic microorganisms in the blood stream causing a rapidly progressing systemic reaction that may lead to shock. Symptoms include fever, chills, tachycardia, and increased respiratory rate. It is a medical emergency that requires urgent medical attention.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A tumor-like collection of serum in the tissues.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A collection of serum in the body.
The shaking movement of the whole body or just a certain part of it, often caused by problems of the neurons responsible for muscle action.

A life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical intervention. It is characterized by reduced blood flow that may result in damage of multiple organs. Types of shock include cardiogenic, hemorrhagic, septic, anaphylactic, and traumatic shock.
Neurophysiological and psychological symptoms caused by sudden and unexpected loud noise.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Systemic anaphylaxis is the most dramatic example of an immediate hypersensitivity reaction; is uncommon and unexpected in nature and occasionally results in a fatal outcome.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Progression of anaphylaxis into systemic shock, which is characterized by significant reduction in tissue perfusion which leads to hypoxia and hypotension, and can lead to death if untreated.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Shock resulting from primary failure of the heart in its pumping function, as in myocardial infarction, severe cardiomyopathy, or mechanical obstruction or compression of the heart.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Shock resulting from primary failure of the heart in its pumping function, as in myocardial infarction, severe cardiomyopathy, or mechanical obstruction or compression of the heart.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Shock resulting from insufficient blood volume for the maintenance of adequate cardiac output, blood pressure and tissue perfusion.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Shock resulting from insufficient blood volume for the maintenance of adequate cardiac output, blood pressure and tissue perfusion.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A hypoglycemic reaction to overdosage of insulin, a skipped meal, or strenuous exercise in an insulin-dependent diabetic.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A hypoglycemic reaction to overdosage of insulin, a skipped meal, or strenuous exercise in an insulin-dependent diabetic.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Shock resulting from neurogenic vasodilation, which can be produced by cerebral trauma or hemorrhage, spinal cord injury, deep general or spinal anesthesia, or toxic central nervous system depression.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Shock resulting from neurogenic vasodilation, which can be produced by cerebral trauma or hemorrhage, spinal cord injury, deep general or spinal anesthesia, or toxic central nervous system depression.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A state of shock following a surgical operation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A state of shock following a surgical operation.
A state of acute circulatory failure characterized by persistent arterial hypotension despite adequate fluid resuscitation or by tissue hypoperfusion unexplained by other causes.
Hypoperfusion of body tissues occurring during or after a surgical procedure, and resulting in cellular injury and vital organ dysfunction.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Any shock produced by trauma.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Any shock produced by trauma.
A rupture in the sinus tissue due to traumatic or pathologic processes.

An autoimmune disorder affecting the salivary and lacrimal glands. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of lymphocytic and plasmacytic infiltrates which cause destruction of these glands. It results in dry mouth and dry eyes. It may be associated with the presence of other autoimmune disorders, including rheumatoid arthritis and lupus erythematosus.
Abnormal skin coloration.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A gradual breakdown or very shallow ulceration of the skin which involves only the epidermis and heals without scarring.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Tearing or wearing off of skin.
An inflammatory process affecting the skin. Signs include red rash, itching, and blister formation. Representative examples are contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.
A mild inflammatory dermal tissue reaction; it can be caused by physical contact with an irritant or can be a local response to a systemic trigger.
A break in skin tissue caused by friction or shearing.
A change from the patient's baseline sleeping pattern, in the hours slept and/or an alteration/dysfunction in the stages of sleep.
A symptom consisting of the involuntary expulsion of air from the nose.
Any kind of inflammatory process of the tonsils, pharynx, or/and larynx characterized by pain in swallowing.
Traumatic damage of the spinal cord.
Damage to the spine that results in impaired function.
A stretching or tearing of a ligament.
An electrocardiographic finding of ST segment depression below the baseline, often described as up sloping, down sloping or horizontal.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Evaluation of the interval from the end of ventricular depolarization to the onset of the T wave; it is usually isoelectric in normal subjects.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding of ST segment elevation above the baseline.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Condition where there are a greater number of inhalations relative to the number of exhalations.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Condition where there are a greater number of inhalations relative to the number of exhalations.

A common bacterial species found especially on nasal mucous membrane and skin (hair follicles); bacterial species that produces exotoxins including those that cause toxic shock syndrome, with resulting skin rash, and renal, hepatic, and central nervous system disease, and an enterotoxin associated with food poisoning; it causes furunculosis, cellulitis, pyemia, pneumonia, osteomyelitis, endocarditis, suppuration of wounds, other infections; also a cause of infection in burn patients; humans are the chief reservoir.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Narrowing or stricture of a duct or canal.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Narrowing or stricture of a vessel, duct or canal.
Limited mobility of the neck, usually accompanied by pain.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Chocking or arrest of respiration due to occlusion of the air passageway; arrest of circulation in a part due to compression.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Chocking or arrest of respiration due to occlusion of the air passageway; arrest of circulation in a part due to compression.
An unexpected natural death from a cardiac cause within a short time period from the onset of symptoms.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The stopping of respiration or the asphyxia that results from it.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The stopping of respiration or the asphyxia that results from it.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Decentration, or malposition of intraocular lens; zonular dehiscence or lens malposition caused by zonular or parsplana fixation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Decentration, or malposition of intraocular lens; zonular dehiscence or lens malposition caused by zonular or parsplana fixation.
Wearing away of the surface of a suture as a result of bending and frictional forces.
A watery secretion by the sweat glands that is primarily composed of salt, urea and minerals.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.
The presence of an enlarged lymph node.
A spontaneous loss of consciousness caused by insufficient blood supply to the brain.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inflammation of a synovial membrane.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammation of a synovial membrane.
An abnormally rapid heart rate. Thresholds for different age, gender, and patient populations exist.
Profuse lacrimation.
Pain or discomfort caused by exposure of the dentin layer of tooth to thermal, tactile, or other stimuli.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Pertaining to tears involving the tentorium of the cerebellum.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Pertaining to tears involving the tentorium of the cerebellum.
The result of processes that negatively affect a developing fetus.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
Unanticipated desirable and beneficial effects resulting from a medical treatment.
A reduction in the desirable and beneficial effects resulting from a medical treatment.
An increase in the desirable and beneficial effects resulting from a medical treatment.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A full thickness burn that extends into deeper tissues causing white or blackened and charred skin that may be numb.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An injury that includes all skin layers into the subcutaneous tissue due to chemical, friction, radiation or thermal exposure. The affected area appears dry and thickened; damage to nerve endings usually renders the wound painless.
Occlusion of the lumen of a vessel by a thrombus that has migrated from a distal site via the blood stream.
The formation of a blood clot in the lumen of a vessel or heart chamber; causes include coagulation disorders and vascular endothelial injury.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An aggregation of blood factors, primarily platelets and fibrin with entrapment of cellular elements, frequently causing vascular obstruction at the point of its formation.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An aggregation of blood factors, primarily platelets and fibrin with entrapment of cellular elements, frequently causing vascular obstruction at the point of its formation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A sensation as of repetitive pin pricks, caused by cold or by striking a nerve, or as a result of various diseases of the central or peripheral nervous system.
