CodeItem.nci_definition: A sensation as of repetitive pin pricks, caused by cold or by striking a nerve, or as a result of various diseases of the central or peripheral nervous system.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A noise in the ears, such as ringing, buzzing, roaring, clicking.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Abnormal perception of sounds experienced by an individual in the absence of auditory stimulation.

A process caused by injury or disease or aging and characterized by a partial/complete disruption of tissue. The disruption may be temporary or permanent and may be associated with either (1) impairment or (2) loss of function of the affected organ(s) or system(s).

CodeItem.fda_definition: Fringe of pointed tips; An atypical rapid ventricular tachycardia with periodic waxing and waning of amplitude of the QRS complexes on the electrogram as well as rotation of the complexes about the isoelectric line.
CodeItem.nci_definition: An electrocardiographic finding of an atypical rapid polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic rotation of the QRS complex around the isoelectric baseline, occurring in the setting of a prolonged QT interval. In addition, the QRS complex displays a periodic waxing and waning of amplitude on the electrocardiogram.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The condition resulting from the spread of bacterial products (toxins) by the bloodstream.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The condition resulting from the spread of bacterial products (toxins) by the bloodstream.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A severe illness caused by infection with staphylococcus aureus and characterized by high fever of sudden onset, vomiting, diarrhea, and myalgia, followed by hypotension and in severe cases, shock; a sunburn-like rash with peeling of the skin, especially of the palms and soles, occurs during the acute phase.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A rare acute life-threatening systemic bacterial noncontagious illness caused by any of several related staphylococcal exotoxins. It is characterized by high fever, hypotension, rash, multi-organ dysfunction, and cutaneous desquamation during the early convalescent period. The toxins affect the host immune system, causing an exuberant and pathological host inflammatory response. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis, elevated prothrombin time, hypoalbuminemia, hypocalcemia, and pyuria.
The finding of bodily harm due to the poisonous effects of something.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Children affected by toxins may be due to silicone breast implants and their effects on unborn children and from breastfeeding.
Acquired as an adult.
Passed from mother to fetus.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Toxoplasma infection that is present from birth.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A brief attack (from a few minutes to an hour) of cerebral dysfunction of vascular origin, with no persistent neurological deficit.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A brief attack (from a few minutes to an hour) of cerebral dysfunction of vascular origin, with no persistent neurological deficit.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Incomplete closure of the tricuspid valve, resulting in tricuspid regurgitation; it is usually secondary to systolic overload in the right ventricle.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Dysfunction of the pulmonary valve characterized by incomplete valve closure.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The backflow of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium, owning to imperfect functioning/insufficiency of the tricuspid valve.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The backflow of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium, owning to imperfect functioning/insufficiency of the tricuspid valve.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Narrowing or stricture of the tricuspid orifice of the heart.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Narrowing or stricture of the tricuspid orifice of the heart.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Dislodgement, breakdown, or other malfunction of an artificial cardiac pacemaker, chemotherapy port, drip infusion valve, or similar implanted diagnostic or therapeutic device as a result of unconscious or habitual manipulation by the patient.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Dislodgement, breakdown, or other malfunction of an artificial cardiac pacemaker, chemotherapy port, drip infusion valve, or similar implanted diagnostic or therapeutic device as a result of unconscious or habitual manipulation by the patient.

CodeItem.fda_definition: The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle.
CodeItem.nci_definition: The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle.

CodeItem.fda_definition: For complications that occur secondary to intraocular lens implantation in the anterior chamber; caused by rubbing of the lens loop (haptics).
CodeItem.nci_definition: Clinical triad of uveitis, glaucoma, and hyphema (UGH), especially associated with the early anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL).Glaucoma is believed to be caused by movement of the IOL against the iris causing release of inflammatory and red blood cell debris, which obstruct the trabecular meshwork. The haptic also may cause direct damage to the trabecular meshwork contributing to the glaucoma. Incidence of UGH is dependent on both surgical methodology applied in the cataract population and type of IOL used. UGH is particularly common if metal clip lenses have been used. Components of the condition may be reversed if the offending IOL is removed before permanent damage has occurred.
A circumscribed inflammatory and often suppurating lesion on the skin or an internal mucous surface resulting in necrosis of tissue.
The formation or development of an ulcer.
An inadequate amount of a treatment.
A laboratory test result indicating abnormally high concentration of non-protein nitrogen in the blood.
Urination at short intervals; it may result from increased urine formation, decreased bladder capacity, or lower urinary tract irritation.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Accumulation of urine within the bladder because of the inability to urinate.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Accumulation of urine within the bladder because of the inability to urinate.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Urticaria.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A transient, itchy skin eruption characterized by wheals with pale interiors and red margins.
A rupture in the uterus due to traumatic or pathologic processes.

An inflammatory process affecting a part of or the entire uvea. Causes include inflammatory agents (e.g., herpes simplex, herpes zoster, leptospirosis) and systemic diseases (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, ankylosing spondylitis). Patients present with pain and redness in the eye, light sensitivity, and blurred and decreased vision.

Normal or abnormal secretions from the vagina. Mucus produced by the cervical glands is discharged from the vagina naturally, especially during the childbearing years. Causes of abnormal vaginal discharge include infectious agents (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas, and Candida albicans), the presence of foreign bodies, and cervical or vaginal cancer.
Narrowing of the opening of one or more of the four valves of the heart.
Vasoconstriction involves narrowing of a blood vessel lumen due to smooth muscle contraction in the vessel wall and leads to decreased blood flow.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A state of increased caliber of the blood vessels.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Vasodilation involves widening of a blood vessel lumen due to smooth muscle relaxation in the vessel wall and leads to increased blood flow.

Sudden drop of the blood pressure, bradycardia, and peripheral vasodilation that may lead to loss of consciousness. It results from an increase in the activity of the vagus nerve. It may be triggered by emotions of fear or pain or gastrointestinal upset and may be relieved by lying down while keeping the legs elevated.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Any contagious disease acquired during sexual contact; e.g. syphilis, gonorrhea, chancroid.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A disorder acquired through sexual contact.
The collection of blood from a vein, most commonly via needle venipuncture.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Arrhythmia characterized by fibrillary contractions of the ventricular muscle due to rapid repetitive excitation of myocardial fibers without coordinated contraction of the ventricle.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a rapid grossly irregular ventricular rhythm with marked variability in QRS cycle length, morphology, and amplitude. The rate is typically greater than 300 bpm. (CDISC)

CodeItem.fda_definition: A ventricular tachyarrhythmia characterized electrocardiographically by smooth undulating waves with QRS complexes merged with T waves, a rate of approximately 250 per minute.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of a high ventricular rate (180 to 250 beats per minute) with a regular rhythm and large oscillating sine wave-like complexes occurring as a result of QRS complexes and T waves being merged. The P wave is not visible.

CodeItem.fda_definition: An abnormally rapid ventricular rhythm with aberrant ventricular excitation, usually in excess of 150 beats per minute.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A disorder characterized by an electrocardiographic finding of three or more consecutive complexes of ventricular origin with a rate greater than a certain threshold (100 or 120 beats per minute are commonly used). The QRS complexes are wide and have an abnormal morphology. (CDISC)

A feeling of movement, a sensation as if the external world were revolving around the patient (objective vertigo) or as if he himself were revolving in space (subjective vertigo). Vertigo is medically distinct from dizziness, lightheadedness, and unsteadiness.

CodeItem.fda_pt: Vessel Or Plaque, Device Embedded In
CodeItem.fda_synonym: Device Embedded In Vessel Or Plaque
Plaque Or Vessel, Device Embedded In
CodeItem.fda_definition: Device and/or fragments of device are embedded in patient's vessel and/or plaque.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A medical device that is located within a blood vessel wall or plaque.
Damage to a blood vessel resulting from a full thickness disruption in the integrity of the vessel wall.

An infectious agent which consists of two parts, genetic material and a protein coat. These organisms lack independent metabolism, and they must infect the cells of other types of organisms to reproduce. Most viruses are capable of passing through fine filters that retain bacteria, and are not visible through a light microscope.
Sight that is impaired.
An interference to normal eyesight.
Surgical removal of the vitreous humor from the chamber of the eye.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Spots before the eyes; deposits in the vitreous of the eye, usually moving about and probably representing fine aggregates of vitreous protein occurring as a benign degenerative change.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Spots before the eyes caused by opaque cell fragments in the vitreous humor or lens.
Blood extravasation in the vitreous humor. Causes include neovascularization, retinal tear, retinal detachment, and rupture of a blood vessel aneurysm in the eye.
Detachment of the vitreous humor from the retina.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Inflammatory intraocular reaction with clouding and cells in vitreous; often accompanies inflammation of ciliary body, iris, choroid, or retina.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Inflammatory intraocular reaction with clouding and cells in vitreous; often accompanies inflammation of ciliary body, iris, choroid, or retina.
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth.
The property of lacking physical strength.
Repetitive loss and regain of body weight.

CodeItem.fda_definition: A smooth, slightly elevated area on the body surface, which is redder or paler than the surrounding skin. It is the typical lesion of urticaria, the dermal evidence of allergy, and in sensitive persons may be provoked by mechanical irritation of the skin.
CodeItem.nci_definition: A smooth, slightly elevated area on the body surface, which is redder or paler than the surrounding skin. It is the typical lesion of urticaria, the dermal evidence of allergy, and in sensitive persons may be provoked by mechanical irritation of the skin.

CodeItem.fda_definition: Separation of the layers of a surgical wound; it may be partial and superficial only, or complete with disruption of all layers.
CodeItem.nci_definition: Splitting of the sutured margins of a surgical wound. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, obesity, and advanced age.
Infection of a surgical skin incision.
Infection of a wound following trauma.
Rupture of the fibrous strands connecting the ciliary body and the crystalline lens of the eye.
